metadata.case_name: Hindu Undivided Family (Appellant) v. Commissioner of Income-tax (Respondent)

facts.text: Appellant is a Hindu undivided family, registered holder of 1,500 shares of M/s Govan Bros. Rampur Ltd.
Appellant's year of account: October 1, 1950 to September 30, 1951, corresponding to assessment year 1952-53.
Board of directors of Govan Bros. passed resolution at meeting on August 30, 1950 to declare interim dividend.
Appellant received dividend warrant dated December 28, 1950 for Rs. 4,12,500 as interim dividend.
Revenue authorities taxed the dividend in assessment year 1952-53, rejecting appellant's objection that it pertained to 1951-52.
Appellate Tribunal referred question to Punjab High Court under s. 66(1) of Indian Income-tax Act in I.T.R. No. 16 of 1959.
Punjab High Court answered question in affirmative by judgment dated March 6, 1961.
Govan Bros. registered under Companies Act of former Rampur State, adopted special Articles of Association superseding Table A.

Relevant articles: Art. 73 (company in general meeting may declare dividend), Art. 74 (directors may declare interim dividend when profits permit), Art. 77 (no dividend except out of net profits, not larger than recommended by directors), Art. 80 (dividends payable by cheque or warrant).
No evidence of actual payment, credit in books, or distribution before close of appellant's year ending September 30, 1950; resolution of August 30, 1950 not on record.

legal_issues.text: Whether on true interpretation of Article 74 of Articles of Association of Govan Bros. (or Article 95 of First Schedule to Indian Companies Act, 1913), the interim dividend of Rs. 4,12,500 was liable to be included in assessment year 1952-53 or 1951-52.
Whether interim dividend declared by directors becomes taxable as income under s. 16(2) of Indian Income-tax Act on date of declaration or only when paid, credited, or distributed.

petitioner_arguments.text: Directors declared interim dividend on August 30, 1950 under authority of Article 74, creating a debt due to appellant, taxable in assessment year 1951-52 as previous year ended September 30, 1951.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Article 74 of Articles of Association; general principle that declaration creates debt

petitioner_arguments.text: Resolution followed by dividend warrants dated December 28, 1950 evidences declaration creating enforceable right.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Laxmidas Mulraj Khatau

respondent_arguments.text: Interim dividend taxable under s. 16(2) of Indian Income-tax Act only in year paid, credited, or distributed; paid by warrant on December 28, 1950.
Directors' resolution to pay interim dividend does not create enforceable obligation as it can be rescinded before payment.

court_reasoning.text: Declaration of dividend by company in general meeting creates enforceable debt, but directors' resolution for interim dividend does not, as it can be rescinded before payment.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Resolution of directors on August 30, 1950 created no enforceable right until implemented by payment.

court_reasoning.text: s. 16(2) deems dividend income of previous year in which paid, credited, distributed, or deemed so; no fiction for declaration alone.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Dividend paid on December 28, 1950, taxable in year of payment.

court_reasoning.text: Article 74 authorizes directors to declare interim dividend, but unlike Table A reg. 96 (pay), still revocable; no difference in legal effect.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No evidence of credit, distribution, or implementation before relevant date.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes Laxmidas Mulraj Khatau as applying to cases where dividend paid, not contingent; literal construction of 'paid' not requiring cashing warrant, but discharge of liability making amount available.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature did not equate 'paid' with 'declared'; different heads of income have specific accrual rules.

holdings.text: Interim dividend declared by directors under articles is not income until paid, credited, or distributed under s. 16(2); directors' declaration revocable, no enforceable debt.
Dividend of Rs. 4,12,500 liable to tax in assessment year 1952-53.

precedents_cited.case_name: In re Severn and Wye and Severn Bridge Railway Company
precedents_cited.relevance: Declaration by company in general meeting creates immediate debt enforceable by shareholder.

precedents_cited.case_name: The Lagunas Nitrate Company Limited v. J. Henry Schroeder and Company
precedents_cited.relevance: Directors can rescind resolution to pay interim dividend before payment; no enforceable right arises.

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay v. Laxmidas Mulraj Khatau
precedents_cited.relevance: Applies to dividends actually paid, not contingent liabilities; 'paid' not equated to 'declared' universally.

precedents_cited.case_name: Purshotamdas Thakurdas v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Bombay City
precedents_cited.relevance: Legislature did not intend to equate 'paid' with 'declared' in every case; distinguishes contingent from paid dividends.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act
statutes_cited.relevance: s. 16(2) deems dividend income of year paid, credited, or distributed; other sections for different income heads.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Companies Act, 1913
statutes_cited.relevance: Reg. 95: Company may declare dividends not exceeding directors' recommendation; Reg. 96: Directors may pay interim; Reg. 97: Out of profits.

statutes_cited.name: Rampur State Companies Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Provisions identical to Indian Companies Act, 1913.

statutes_cited.name: Finance Act, 1959
statutes_cited.relevance: Deleted s. 16(2) of Income-tax Act effective April 1, 1960.

outcome.summary: The Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, affirming the Punjab High Court's order that the interim dividend was liable to tax in assessment year 1952-53, as it was paid on December 28, 1950, and directors' declaration did not create an enforceable debt.

key_quotes.text: "A directors declaration of an interim dividend may be rescinded before payment has been made." (Halsbury)
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Confirms revocability of interim dividend declaration by directors.

key_quotes.text: "For the purposes of inclusion in the total income of an assessee any dividend shall be deemed to be income of the previous year in which it is paid, credited or distributed..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes s. 16(2) defining taxability of dividends.

key_quotes.text: "the mere fact that the actual payment of the income is deferred is immaterial and irrelevant." (Chagla C.J. in Laxmidas case, distinguished)
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner_counsel
key_quotes.significance: Appellant's relied principle rejected as not equating declaration to payment under IT Act.
